label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, June 22, 1943

M 6 24 43
R 7 1 43
June 22nd
Dear Sidney,
I contacted Clarence off to-day to see if there was any let
down on Naval restrictions that might permit me to get to you. The answer
was none. It appears the only chance is if you own property out there and are
a resident. I strongly suggestthat you buy a nice bungalow, become a property
holder and send for me. There may be a way that way, and that way only.
I wanted to make good and sure I was n't off in the wrong direction. I am
slated now to leave for the Ivy. Ofcourse I dont know when or on what., but
I think it may be on a"queen." I have told Rose of my appraoching move[,]
and we are now in the throws of finding a light trunk to squeeze all my p
possessions into,as one is allowed 175 lbs. including all. I am planning to
take plenty of warm clothes, lipsticks and stockings which you cant buy there[,]
and will probably stay at Claridges. Write me [percent] American Embassy as it is next
door to where I work. American Embassy -Grosvenor Square. I doubt it I
get off before three weeks from to-day but you never know. I am telephoning
you to-night. The mails are so punk now the letters dont get ehre for long --
spells. Your last was June 10th. They never come airmail anymore.
Be sure and send me a cable if you change or move or anything.
The American Embassy will always reach me. If you get leave for god sakes let m
me know at once because I would want to return emmediately to Washington
- and can do so. Dont think I would n't[,]believe me. I canr_esign anytime and
besides - it would be a "trasfer" not resignation anyhow. Being a civilian I
am free as air,and passage home is easy by comparison to passage over.
The strikes and Race riots are so discourraging it makes you
mad as hell. It hardly seem conceivable it can happen. I am sure they are axe
inspired. They must be.The war front news is so good it makes you sick to have
the home front news so lousy. I shall be thrilled to get closer to what is
going on,even though my heart is in the Pacific and not the Atlantic.
It is a break to leave Washington and work in a different setting. I have no
idea if the job will be as good or as importent,but afterall my work is not my
career so I dont really care much.
I am enclosing some clippings to amuse you. I wonder how much
news you get. I immagine Time and Life are your standbys.
The weather is about the same. infact everything is the same.
The only new face is that of Maurice Fatio. I bycicle home up to Georgetown
in a lather and stand under a cold shower for fifteen minutes till its
time to dress. What a great life this city really is! Hotcha!
[June 22nd P.M. written in margin] Your island life is so perfect compared to my fetid city existane
I never was made for desk life in a big city, you once thought you were,but
I never did. You[']r[e] leading life I like[,]and I am leading the life you though[t]
you would like it. Its has humor.
Since talking to you on the telephone this afternoon I have
found out that a one - Mary Kay Potter is planning to go out there as a guest
of a property owner.I doubt if that works but there may be something in
actual"ownership." Ellen Dupuy should do the byuing if there is any and then sh
can get there to see her property. Having only just heard of this angle I
[End Page 1]
2
sent you you that wire suggesting ti.
[June 23rd]
Thismorning first thing I went to see Atherton R[i]chards.Do you know his name? [H]e
owns vast property in Hawaii and gave me a great deal of good sound advice.This isit[!]
Be sure and see all the surrounding isla[n]d[s]before buying an Awahou. He tells me [hand drawn arrow in margin]
Honolulu and surroundings will never quite be the same after the war. Too many
people will stay on. Business will increase, the airfileds will grow,your neighbors
are apt to be less pleasant. He strongly advises that if one wishes to settle somewher
to see all, look everything over. Kawai [or a name like that] he claims is marvelous.
He tells me there are ranc_hing islands, islands with mountsin that rise 1400 ft.
every sort of climate and fishing, He advises not to buy but build, he said think aft[er]
this war what new insulating materials there will be, the modern side of everything
from termite proof composition floors to air conditioning, heliocoptar garage etc. etc.
The world will be different, the planes will bring you everywhere in short [o]rder. Dist[-]
ance will be nothing. He was charming to me. We talked a long time. He called up a
freind in 02 to find out about transportation out there. He was told every civilian
must be passed on by the Commandant of the 12 Naval District in SanRransisco,and that
only in the roll of the JOB was their a prayer of getting out. The Army man did not
think even owning property would do it for a navy wife. I am going to work awfully
hard on that angle. For some strange reason when it rains it pours. Just because I
a m ready, able and set to go to the IVY things have broken in other directions too.
There is a clew even in this office now that may lead to something. Icant write it
all out on paper, but there is a straw in the wind brewing, brewing for only the last
24 hours. If between now and the time my boat sails for Ivy I should get a real
lead- why ofcourse then I will never get on that boat. I will turn all attention to
the Pacific, to the islands, to reaching you. Is N't it funny how things work. Is n'tt
strange. When I spoke to you on the phone yesterday I was overcome with emotion. I
just cant tell you how it felt to hear your voice[,]and to know I was planning to go
even further away from you, even away from a possible telephone converstaion with
you. I wanted s to see you, to hug, to hold on to you. But I wont go into my feelings
because its useless and senseless and just makes us both feel badly all over again.
I lay in bed all night wide awake thinking, worrying and crying. Its such hell.
I know Hawaii would be a heaven spot to live in. I am convinced its the
type of life we both love. There is ranching, there is business to be done to keep
from a complete Lotis life if need be[,]and it is paradice! the flowers, the sea, the ai
air , the sun. Atherton Richards tells me he just cant wait to get back there. It has
everything. He claims he would not live anywhere else in the world. His interests
out thereare vast and many. I believe the pinapples are his show. He also talked
about land, sales etc. He thinks now is the time to sell land in the U.S. because now
is the time everyone is looking for it. He thinks that after the war there maybe so ma [hand drawn arrow in margin]
many new marerials that wood will be substituted for[,]and that perhaps timber will
not bring the price we think it will. He was awfully nice. He gave me even the name
of a construction Co in N.Y.C. to go and see.He thought they might give me a job to 
go out there for them as they are an enormous concern that operate in Hawaii[,]and do
all the work for the Navy. Turner is the name. I am going to try every clue between
now and a month from now. If the prospects are good at all I shall not go to IVY.
Why things should pick up overnight I dont know. It is all so sudden .I am in a tail
spin. Since starting this letter my information has developed and increased and this
letter was only started yesterday morning. Its a queer world. On the other hand of cours[e]
if there turns out to be no way of working a job angle on getting out- then I want to
hold on to the Ivy trip because The General and David have gone to alot of trouble [hand drawn arrow in margin]
to send me[,]and I would not want to let them down unless it was to assuredly get to you
Getting to you cancels everything in my eyes, and [I] immagine I would be forgiven anyho[w]
as everyone knows how I feel about getting out there.
[End Page 2]
3
Jim Forestal has asked me to play tennis this afternoon. I have secured
special permission to levveand hour early in order to try and work
on him. You never know. Thts how things are done. Everything is hap-
pening to me at once. I am all steamed up and nothing will probably
happen at all. But believe me I am going ot try.
Think I will continue this letter from the house after I have seen
Jim.
Just finished a game of singles with Jim. We palyed at Nelson Rockerfe
eller's house. We got to six all and I was so pooped and out of condition 
I never hit an other thing hardly for the whole ne[x]t set. I was beaten
8-5 6-2. It was fun, but my I am soft. Cant run a yard. I was so tired
I thought I would die.
I did n't get much out of Jim except that he would write a letter for m[e]
to the Head of the 12th Naval District Sanfransisco when I had a job lined
up- so I can get transpotation out. That is something anyhow.
Well as I know no more I shallsay goodnight and go on working on that
little project until the boat sails getting me the otherd[i]rection to
Ivy. You never know. Things always happen at once. Something perfect
may break yet before I pull out in the wrong direction.
Lets both pray doodle ears and I may get there. I want to so terribly
badly.
Goodnight and all my love to you always.
Gertie
June 24th.
My transpotation to Ivy materialises about the First Day of August or
last day of July.
Still no letter f rom you since June 10th.
[End Page 3]
